newsitem.title: USA: VF sets $1.25 bln investment in brands.
newsitem.headline: VF sets $1.25 bln investment in brands.

text.p: VF Corp said Tuesday it intends to invest $1.25 billion in its brands over the next four years.
The company also said it plans to invest $150 million in a new organizational structure designed to free up resources for the brand investments.
The company's statement made no reference to job cuts which a Wall Street Journal report said the restructuring would cause. A VF spokeswoman said she had no knowledge of any upcoming job cuts.
Stating the program is designed to create $2 billion in new annual sales by 2000, she said this would result in the creation of jobs.

Stating the brand investment is based on strategies put into motion last year, chief executive Mackey J. McDonald said, "We will make an unprecedented push behind our strongest product categories -- jeanswear, intimate apparel, workwear and daypacks -- to spur renewed growth in sales.
"Over the next four years, we intend to invest a total of $1.25 billion behind our brands, including $250 million" in consumer research, product development and marketing.

"That strategy, which we call 'consumerization', ... is also the driving force behind our move to a new, more efficient organizational structure, one that is designed to keep our brands closer to consumers and free up resources for our brand investments."

McDonald said the "new" VF will consist of five coalitions -- North and South American Jeanswear, Intimate Apparel, Knitwear, Playwear and International -- each of which supports a number of marketing companies.

"Over the next several years, we will consolidate within these coalitions much of the manufacturing and administrative functions now duplicated across 17 separate divisions, a monumental task given the breadth and diversity of our operations," McDonald said.
"As part of this move, a newly established Service Center has been created in Greensboro, North Carolina to centralize information systems and transaction processing for all our domestic operations."
To accomplish this reorganization will require investment of about $150 million over the next several years.
"However, by the time we've finished, we expect to realize ongoing, annual savings of at least this magnitude," he said.
